description: The London-based Wellcome Trust has announced the winners of its Image Awards. The winning image shows a skeleton and depicts the experience of Crohn's disease.
title: Wellcome Trust announces winners of its 2017 Image Awards
title_page: Wellcome Trust announces winners of its 2017 Image Awards  | Daily Mail Online
text:
After months of anticipation, the Wellcome Trust has announced the 22 winners of its 2017 Image Awards.
From striking computer-generated images, to stunning microscopic photographs, the judging panel had a tough time whittling down the competition.
An image by photographer Oliver Burston titled ‘Stickman- The Vicissitudes of Crohn’s (Resolution)’, which conveys the physical and emotional experience of Crohn’s disease, was selected as the overall winner.
Fergus Walsh, BBC Medical Correspondent and member of the judging panel said: 'This image is a stunning representation of what it must be like to have Crohn’s disease and it’s like nothing I’ve seen before in terms of the portrayal of someone’s condition: it conveys the pain and torment the sufferer must go through.
‘The image really resonates and is beautifully composed: it’s a haunting piece.'
The Julie Dorrington Award was also given for outstanding photography in a clinical environment.
The winner was a detailed close-up photograph by Mark Bartley, showing how an ‘iris clip’ – a device used to treat cataracts - is fitted onto the eye. Iris clips are used to treat near sightedness and cataracts.
Catherine Draycott, Head of Wellcome Images and chair of the judging panel, explained: 'This extreme close-up shows the expertise of the clinical photographer in illustrating with such clarity and precision this minuscule lens that, clipped by a surgeon into the human iris itself, can restore a patient’s vision.'
Other award-winning images include a beautiful illustration of Nobel laureate and neurobiologist Rita Levi-Montalcini, a glimpse at the intricate system of blood vessels inside an African Grey Parrot and a fascinating visualisation of Twitter conversations about breast cancer.
The images will also be displayed in the windows of Wellcome’s HQ in London.
